I hadn't seen any trailers and knew nothing about it, just that it was based on a new book by Suzanne Collins.I had absolutely zero expectations, although the cynical part of me thought I might be wasting my time, especially after seeing the runtime on the movie. However, 3 hours later I can admit I left the cinema feeling rather impressed. I genuinely enjoyed it.While the hunger games trilogy we know with Katniss Everdeen strike me as a fun, rewatchable teen-fantasy, in the Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, we see a much darker and grittier side of the world of Panem, which I felt resulted in experiencing a much more horrifying reality of the games themselves. It felt more real, and grounded, and loved seeing how everything operated with far more inferior technology and fewer established rules.Since watching the movie I've seen criticism of the characters and acting, and while I am usually quite strict on that kind of thing too, I genuinely see their points here. I understand Rachel Zegler is an actress of controversy for a lot of people, I myself have seen a lot of debatable interviews with her, but I believe she shows of her talent here with a great performance. The standout performance is definitely Tom Blyth and a young president Snow however, an actor who I have not seen in anything else before. I found myself genuinely caring about the fate of the two characters and their relationship, which is a hard thing to achieve, and i feel is the core element of this movie, therefore really enjoyed because of it. The supporting characters were also well performed, such as Peter Dinklage and Viola Davis.The movie is split into three chapters, like a book. Chapters 1 and 2 are certainly the stronger of the three, which I very much enjoyed for reasons already stated. Despite still enjoying chapter 3, and completely recognising it's importance, I feel as though it was slightly rushed, and therefore perhaps would be understood more by people who have read the book and have pre-existing knowledge of the hunger games.Although certainly not a flawless movie, I am pleasantly surprised by it and had a fun time watching. I would recommend if you fancy a movie night. 7.5/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: "The Mockingjay" book has been adapted into 2 movies for no good reason and it went terrible. The producers learned a hard lesson, but now it seems like it was even too hard for them, cause "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" feels like it has adapted two books into one movie, even thought it didn't.This movie has some serious timing problems. It's definitely too long, but at the same time manages to make you feel like the second part of it is too short and should be extended. I feel like it should be separated into two movies. One about the 10th Hunger Games and the rise of Snow (this doesn't really need much more, that the first hour and a half of this movie) and another one about how he turned from an ambitious boy in love to a overambitious manipulator and tyrant (this one definitely needs more time and depth).The most frustrating thing about the new Hunger Games movie is that literally every element of it is interesting, but still none of them is really well done and fulfills its potential. The main character is interesting, writers try to make him deep, they almost succed, but then they don't have enough time to finish the job, cause the movie cannot be even longer than it actually is.In the end, I feel so much wasted potential that it makes me angry, even thought I'm not really emotionally invested in the franchise.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: As a dedicated fan of dystopian narratives, it pains me to say that the much-anticipated recent Hunger Games adaptation is nothing short of a letdown. Despite high expectations, the film fails to capture the essence of Suzanne Collins' gripping trilogy, leaving audiences yearning for the intensity and emotional depth that defined the source material.From the moment the opening credits begin, it becomes painfully evident that Rachel Zegler's Hunger Games is marred by a sea of cringe-worthy performances that even the most forgiving viewer will struggle to overlook. The cast, including Zegler herself, delivers a collective display of wooden acting that undermines the gravity of the dystopian world they're supposed to inhabit.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The acting wasn't bad, but if you read the book, you will not like the movie. The inner monologue the book gives you, allows you to see that dude is low-key crazy from the very beginning whereas the movie just lead you to believe he snapped at the end. No dude was crazy. One line from the book that sums up he had mental issues from the very beginning was he admitted to himself that he preferred her in the arena because at least he knew where she was, and what she was doing when she was in there as opposed to when they were in district 12, and he didn't know who she was talking to. Those are the thoughts of a narcissistic crazy person.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I was completely uninterested in the film because of the terrible performance and the uninteresting plot. The movie seemed to go on forever, and I found myself fidgeting with my phone multiple times since I was bored with all the dull scenes.Much as in the literature, the characters speak in a similar manner. The acting is top-notch. The scenes are paced appropriately. Still, you don't care about a single plot point since the film is so dull.In comparison to the previous Hunger Games films, this one was terrible. My excitement at the announcement of a new Hunger Games film was palpable because I adored the first four films in the series. There was just too much graphic and pointless violence in this film.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
First, I want to emphasize that I have read the trilogy and watched all the movies.The books, although written, perhaps excessively, in simple language, are easy to read and provide decent entertainment, standing out like a lighthouse amid the vast sea of worthless fiction. On the other hand, the movies based on the trilogy are so powerful and energetic that they have turned Katniss into a symbol.And now, a few words about this movie:
My expectations were, rightly so, enormous-at least 7, maybe even 8 stars. After just half an hour, it became clear to me that this film is simply a waste of time-nothing substantial! Boring, slow, and overacted. Those interested in the series should watch and stick to the movies based on the trilogy, and skip this one. I definitely recommend the books as well (I haven't read this one yet, and probably won't after the movie).

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I really am glad I watched this one in the theaters. "The Hunger Games" is one of the most important dystopian series ever created because it's targeted towards young adults. This franchise is shaping young minds, it's an absolute wonder. Although I miss the frenzy that came with the movie during that era, I am so happy I get to experience a different story in the same universe. In "The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" Snow is the protagonist. A younger maybe more human version of Snow. This is the story about Lucy Gray, but don't get it confused, when the time comes this story can have only one main protagonist and that is Snow. I love everything Francis Lawrence brought to this movie, he knows how to craft them, set the setting and he knows how to navigate us through Panem. I really don't mind how this is a long movie because it's divided in three parts where every single one of them tells a different story about Snow. Every single one of them is essential in realising how he grew into the bloodthirsty,ruthless man that became the President of Panem. Rachel Zegler's Lucy Gray is nothing like Katniss but she has all fascinated with her charm. Viola Davis is so good an actor that she stole every single one of the scenes she is in. She's so fascinatingly evil. I feel like this movie brings a new perspective to the dystopian world of Panem, it brings a new insight in everything that lead to the events of the trilogy and a much needed insight I feel, to the philosophy of the Games as an event. I really am looking forward to reading the book, Suzanne Collins has done it again and I'm falling into the "Hunger Games" spiral once more.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I have seen the movies with Katniss and I liked them. This one not so much. I did not like the female main actress. Her acting was not loveable and I just did not believe it. Why did she have to sing?The writers have been up and down in every corner to make links between this movie and the movies before, but the links could easily be forgotten as well.There were so many flaws and ideas that made no sense at all, like the birds who could copy human voices with a device. What was up at the end of the movie? Since this is a prequel, what kind of effect did it have for the other movies? Was Katniss Snow's child?The only plus was the male actor. But he could not carry the whole movie on his shoulders. This movie is just a waste of my time. It was better if I wasted on Napoleon, but can't go back can I?

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
In the near future "Big Brother" has evolved into "The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes" is the first prequel, set 64 years prior to "The Hunger Games" in a city being rebuilt after a civil war destroyed the Capitol of Panem and obliterated District13.It too is based on a novel written by Suzanne Collins, who also wrote for the Hunger Games trilogy.The director in charge of "The Hunger Games" franchise since 2013 is back, and Francis Lawrence has pulled heavily from the novel.As President Snow (Donald Sutherland) reminded us in the series many times before and again in this telling, "It's the things we love most that destroy us" and this will make even more sense in the movie.The legend that changed the game Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth as a bleached blonde) is a mentor and we watch his change from a person of integrity who steps across that line into evil.At one point in the movie his curly locks are shaved GI Joe style and he's a dead ringer for Eminem.It's only fitting because in this period of his life he loses himself (pardon the pun)...at least his old decent self.Snow has plenty of evil role models including "Dr Casca Highbottom".An ironic name considering he's played by Peter Dinklage...one of the finest actors of my generation.And the other antagonist Viola Davis as snake breeding "Dr Volumnia Gaul" is pure evil...both inspired casting."Tigris Snow" (Hunter Schafer) is Mr Snows only surviving cousin from the Dark Days and there are hints at her fashion designer flair in this movie, of course in the last part of the trilogy Snow tires of his relative and forces her to be tattooed like a Tiger, but she gets her revenge.Every tribute has a story and the main Tribute is Rachel Zegler as "Lucy Gray Baird".In fact, she is the same age that Jennifer Lawrence was when she portrayed "Katniss Everdeen" when the first Hunger Games movie was released.There are a few nods to the Games original heroine "Katniss" in this prequel including her curtsy and a wild flower bearing her name.Lucy loves a singalong...hence "The Ballad of Songbirds" subtitle and at times I though I was watching an episode of "Glee" (just shoot me now).Every saga has a beginning
In this Games there's so many clues this is decades before the original Games movies were set with older technology in TV Monitors, cameras, architecture and even Peace Keepers uniforms (they don't look like Storm Troopers yet).It's got a 50's America vibe, which will tap in nicely to the current retro trend of everything old is new again in 2023.Jason Schwartzman plays the first ever host of The Hunger Games as "Lucky Flickerman" (Weatherman & Magician) is a scene stealer with some of the best lines.He is of course part of a media family dynasty that includes Caesar Flickerman (Stan Tucci) in the original four part trilogy.While not as polished as his Grandson he reminds everyone to "smile..that's why you have teeth" something Caesar took to heart with his cheesy Hollywood smile.Yet again the drones play a part in distributing water and other much needed supplies to the tributes, but it's new technology and they need to iron out a few bugs in these deadly drones.Every movie lately is divided into chapters with titles superimposed on the big screen.I blame the rise of Audiobooks, but I shouldn't complain because I've narrated a few.Listen out for: "Can't Catch Me Now" by Olivia Rodrigo in the closing credits.If you want to know how quickly civilisation disappears you've come to the right movie.Everything is about winning in The Hunger Games saga and this origins movie is no different.Enjoy the show...all 2 hrs 37 Minutes of epic Hunger Games action, adventure and drama.This will be one of the smash hits of Summer 2023!You are invited to return to the Games which have been a welcome addition to our movie universe for over a decade.You just know Snow will land on top, but it's also good to see Snow fall.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I loved the dark totalitarian atmosphere of the original trilogy with fantastic acting, impressive set/costume design, and next-level writing. This movie completely subverts these expectations. Surely it has a different director? Nope-it's the same guy who directed the trilogy. Is it based on a novel by a different author? Nope. Same source material. So how the hell did it go so wrong that it feels like a low-budget Hunger Games live action fan fic courtesy of Kidz Bop and YouTube TV?The moment this movie begins, it feels like an edgy anime show. Exposition hits like a truck, and it's clear the writers don't even remotely trust you to glean that the main cast are elitists without making them the laziest, most one-dimensional portrayals of "elite rich kids" I've seen in years with over-the-top cartoonish snobbiness. "Hello class partner! We do every project together!" "Hello rich dad kid. Surprised your dad bought you out of trouble AGAIN >:(". It's like they constantly tread the line of "show don't tell" so recklessly that even when they're showing, it feels like you're being spoon fed every piece of information they want you to know.The entire premise just doesn't make sense. Why are they trusting 18-year-old kids (played by 28-year-old actors) to mentor contestants in the Hunger Games? Why do they so haphazardly throw together the games? I get that the technology is worse, but they couldn't even clean up the arena the day before the games after it had just been bombed? They couldn't hire more than two Peacekeepers to man the gates? Why does Lucy stop to leave snake traps instead of just escaping? Why do the Peacekeepers gun down multiple contestants who are posing no threat before the games even begin? Why does the main antagonist (Viola Davis) send Snow into the arena to retrieve his friend instead of Peacekeepers who are already at the gates? Whenever they send in donations, the drones accelerate at a dangerous speeds directly into the contestants' faces, and after this happens TWICE even leading to the death of one of the contestants, they still allow this to keep happening to the point that the main character later calls a drone strike that takes out five contestants during a fight, which is deemed totally acceptable.When the love interest girl from District 12 is introduced, she begins singing a song while making overexaggerated facial expressions into the camera, wearing a colorful white dress with a substantial amount of lipstick and makeup. She inexplicably assaults a girl with a snake, which is never mentioned again in the film. And it's later revealed D12 throws frequent musical concerts with high-end guitars, cellos, speakers, and microphones in an underground concert hall, and that they'll sometimes retreat to a lake house wearing comfortable modern swimwear to have fun on vacations. So the people living in the most starved and oppressed district who were fighting tooth and nail for food in the previous movies, living in small, beaten-down wooden buildings, are now living comfortable lifestyles throwing underground Kidz Bop concerts? There's such substantial tonal whiplash that it doesn't even remotely feel like the same universe. How are we supposed to understand these people to be oppressed when every time they're on the screen, they're breaking out into dance and song and going to the lake house for vacations?The music just feels generic-that is, when the movie isn't in musical revolutionary tune mode, at which point you wish Lucy wouldn't overexaggerate every syllable like those Star Spangled Banner performers. The main actor is mediocre and looks/acts like Macklemore with hair that is clearly not naturally blonde. His love interest, coming from extreme poverty, looks, dresses, and acts like a disney princess. The sets are somewhat interesting having a more old-fashioned tone, but it just feels low budget overall, which is surprising considering how this movie had a higher budget than the original Hunger Games. The entire Hunger Games arena was literally just a hastily crafted metal circle. I get these are the days before it was well-developed, but at least give us something. The games didn't feel even remotely dynamic, and the announcer kept saying things at times like "Oops, we don't have a camera there! We'll add one next year". Like did they spend any time planning this? While one of the contestants is dying, the announcer is literally reading the weather on the TV. The ending is undercooked and kind of makes sense, but not completely. Everyone kept calling Lucy Gray by her full name. Lucy Gray, Lucy Gray, Lucy Gray-it never ends. And they also kept calling her "songbird" (because she sings), which of course sounded completely normal to hear over and over across several characters. The love interest had no character arc and was borderline insufferable, and Snow's character arc didn't really feel natural. It felt like his arc evolved wherever the plot needed to go without making logical sense. And of course the main characters are both orphans because every YA novel aggressively fetishizes having a rough upbringing that have no impact on the story.Viola Davis and Peter Dinklage gave the best performances they could have given the writing. Peter Dinklage hated the main character because he is poor and for no other reason (and again, the author takes any excuse for more oppression fetishization... like it's okay if your character is oppressed, but at least explore it rather than just use it as a cheap, unsuccessful ploy to gain audience sympathy). And Viola Davis was a mad scientist for some reason, whom I think gave the strongest performance in the film, which was impressive considering how they dressed her like a clown. But overall, this movie was so, so much worse than the originals. It didn't really do anything well, including worldbuilding, which I was really anticipating. As a standalone movie, it's entertaining enough to be a 5/10, or maybe a bit higher. But as a sequel to such a fantastic trilogy, it was a colossal disappointment, and I'm extremely disheartened they missed such a great opportunity to build in mature ways on the world of Panam.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: At a little after two hours (out of 2 hours and 37 minutes of run time), I couldn't stand it anymore and with no end in sight, I left the theater before I fell into a coma. The 10th Hunger Games was the shortest, least interesting and unchallenging of all. I don't think the actual "game" even lasted 20 minutes. Gone was all the CGI, the different effects and terrains and all the out-of-nowhere things to challenge the players in addition to the tributes trying to kill each other. I found Rachel Zegler's character, Lucy Gray, annoying at every turn, shallow, not particularly clever, with no real depth or even a back story. I wish they'd just have focused almost entirely on the character of Coriolanus Snow, the mentor, who was very interesting and checked off all the personality points that Lucy Gray didn't. I tried to wait to see how his story played out, but even that wasn't worth waiting for. But, ladies and gentlemen, the first Hunger Games Musical! Zegler can barely get through a scene without bursting into song and her W. Virginia twang in both song and speech is over-the-top fake and gets closer and closer to nails on a chalkboard as the movie goes on. If they left out all the singing, the movie could have probably been a half hour shorter. I love Peter Dinklage, but he looked about as bored as I did. In short, if you're going in there looking for signs or similarities to all the other "Hunger Games", skip this because you won't find it. Save yourself the money and time.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: It's been a while since I didn't saw a movie I couldn't finish. I was so excited to watch it since I'm a huge fan of hunger game but it was disappointing. The characters are blend, you don't get attached to them, the pace of the movie is weird it's rushed but at the same time nothing happens. The relationship between Snow and Lucy gray was rushed too and so cringe, like girl you don't fall in love after the 2nd time seeing the person that get pay if you don't die.You know the feeling when you wait for the movie to really start but it never really start? I was able to watch half of the movie out of curiosity but couldn't reach the end, it was too hard to watch.I think I'll just read the book at this point after reading some reviews that say that the movie didn't do justice to the book.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
IN A NUTSHELL:
We get an origin story, of sorts, of President Coriolanus Snow. What the filmmakers are able to show us in only one movie reminded me of Anakin's plunge into the Dark Side that took place in 3 of the Star Wars films.This movie is directed by Francis Lawrence who also directed 3 of the other Hunger Games movies. It's designed as a prequel to the 2012 Hunger Games film. It's supposed to take place 64 years prior.The dramatic film was written by Michael Lesslie, Michael Arndt, and Suzanne Collins. Because they were able to secure an interim agreement from SAG-AFTRA, they were able to market the movie during the 2023 actors' strike.THINGS I LIKED:
Rachel Zegler is so beautiful and has such a lovely voice! She sang all of her songs live on set! I'm excited to see her in Snow White in 2025! She and fellow co-star, Josh Andres Rivera, met while filming the 2021 movie West Side Story together. They're actually dating in real life!Tom Blyth does a great job as Coriolanus Snow. It's fascinating to watch the story unfold when we already know how he ends up in later films. Dexter Sol Answell is completely adorable as the young Coriolanus.Academy Award winner Viola Davis won the role of the villain in this prequel after director Francis Lawrence saw a sinister meme of her that a fan had posted online! She's excellent, of course.I really liked seeing Jason Schwartzman slowly develop the skills he would need later as the flashy Lucretius "Lucky" Flickerman.All of the characters are well defined and it's easy to quickly feel something for them. The cast includes Peter Dinklage, Burn Gorman, Fionnula Flanagan, Pliny Harrington, Festus Creed, and many more.The set designs are outstanding.Cool special effects.The movie definitely isn't a musical, yet music plays a big role in the film and perfectly fits the title of the film. I didn't expect to hear so much music in this! I know, that's silly since the word "ballad" is in the title! I really enjoyed the musical element in the storyline. It gave a real down-to-earth feeling, and the lyrics showed us how much changed and how much remained the same in the districts.I love that costume designer Trish Summerville included Katniss and Primrose flowers on it as a respectful nod to the previous Hunger Games movies. Nice touch!There are several references to the previous films such as when Lucy Gray curtsies at the ceremony like Katniss did in the 2012 movie.I haven't read the book, but I hear it's a very good adaptation!It's fun to see how the Hunger Games were more amateur in the beginning compared to the glossy veneer they acquired over the decades.THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:
Many of the scenes are visually dark, so it'll be hard to see everything that's going on if you watch this on a small streaming device once the film goes to Video on Demand.It seemed ridiculous that Lucy Gray Baird had a beautiful, colorful, and expensive-looking dress while living in a poor district. It was pretty though!Some of the actors deliver lines mechanically.It drove me nuts when Lucy Gray Baird would just sit instead of run away. She seemed super cocky considering she wasn't a very good fighter.All of the characters looked normal, but Viola Davis was so over the top and seemed out of place.While the movie is a prequel to the original trilogy, it's not an origin story of the actual Hunger Games.TIPS FOR PARENTS:
Violence with various weapons and hand-to-hand combat
Explosions and destruction
Some blood and gore
We see people die.If you don't like snakes, you're going to be very uncomfortable watching some of the scenes.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: After the trilogy we were really looking forward to this prequel. If you're wanting the excitement of the trilogy this is a fail. If you're looking for the love story, this is a fail. And if you're looking for a political statement amongst the story this is extremely weak though not a total fail. Don't expect any pomp and circumstances or fantastic outfits either.The characters are shallow, the story line even more so. The angst doesn't come through.It's clear from the get go what motivates Snow--self preservation. Period. But we already knew that from the trilogy. Duh. He didn't wrestle with any moral or ethical questions whatsoever although the weak attempts alluding to such. He has always been an a$$hat.And the son of Plinth?! Srsly unbelievable considering his background and upbringing. And to think that Daddy didn't even attempt to bail him out a last time?! Nawh dawwg. Not buying it.Almost no development of any of the tribute "players". You don't really have anyone but Ms. Gray to root for. And what IS the deal of always using her full name? It's stupid.Acting is very good, as it should be. Effects are few but well done. The weatherman/emcee is the only real connection to what we saw in the trilogy and yet still incomplete.Overall disappointed, would rather have seen it at home.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: An epic character story, Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes gets closer to the origin of how this post-apocalyptic future happens through the eyes of president-to-be Snow. Dramatic elements are heavy, intrigue abounds, politics play their part, and the action sequence provides a hefty dose of tension.Actors/Actresses were the highlight of the film for me, with captivating believability, emotion, and expression. Directing was a close second. CGI was obvious but not as off-putting as earlier 2000s films. A few questionable events at the end were head-scratchers and overall think the film would've been better finished at the climax rather than the downward slope. Still, a very enjoyable movie.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I've read the Hunger Games trilogy several times, including the audiobooks in anticipation of this film. I purposefully did not read the book for this movie, because I like to read the books after. While the rating seems good, I'm not understanding the large number of negative reviews.The Hunger Games is YA - it seems a lot of people are expecting something different. The school setting of the trainers and Viola Davis's character felt very appropriate for the genre, and so did the immature characters. The melodrama between them, and the general focus was exactly as expected. The movie has a PG-13 rating, so while it is a dark story, the violence is toned down. This is not Game of Thrones, despite Peter Dinklage being there. I suspect the lack of intensity might have been an issue in expectations for some. In addition, the games themselves are only one part, rather than the main focus of the film. This is not a sequel meant to relive the original trilogy. Those books and movies stand alone. That saga is complete.However, if you focus on the message and themes, much of the story is actually very striking. Snow is a realistic villain, which is exactly the point. It also occurs in the time of his life when these character developments really occur. He is never a completely sympathetic character because that would not be believable. From the beginning, we can see that he is strategizing more than caring, in contrast to many of his classmates, especially his friend, Plinth. In fact, he is a star mentor right away, attracting the attention of the head game maker, played by Viola Davis. The story is well crafted, and I'm so excited to now fill in the blanks by reading the book. There are indeed hints at unanswered questions.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'm at best a casual Hunger Games fan. I've watched them because my wife wanted to, not normally my thing at all. I eye rolled when told they'd made a prequel.BUT - I'll hold my hands up, I enjoyed it more than I thought.Seeing how Snow becomes the man we know from the later films was quite enjoyable, I get what others are saying about the ending seeming quite rushed when we start to see his true colours though. I think I'd have enjoyed a more nuanced approach to this. But it really didn't ruin anything the way it was done.I see a lot of complaints complaining that it wasn't a faithful adaption of the book. I've never read the book so I can't speak to that but I can count on one hand the amount of books I've read that have been faithfully translated to screen - It almost never happens the way that satisfies everyone, people should be used to that by now.As for the songs been complained about, well perhaps they should try listening to them - I thought they helped convey a lot of narrative and emotion and the film would be missing something more without them. And for those comparing this to a musical because of them, then they should probably go and watch a musical to find out how wrong they are there as well. Ridiculous statements.Was / is it the best film ever? No. Of course not.Does it deserve the panning some people give it based on it not being an accurate representation of the book? Nope.Does it deserve to be slagged off for being a musical? Nope.Does it deserve a watch if you've any interest in the Hunger Games world? Absolutely.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
POSITIVES:1) I thought all of the central performances were excellent. They made all of the main characters feel very engaging and I was locked in for the whole film
2) I loved the darkness of the film and of this series in general. It feels right on the border between a film for teens and a film for adults and I think that's a really good place to be. The inner turmoil and conflict that the two leads feel throughout the film is very powerful, as well as the outer turmoil and conflict that is happening throughout the events of the film
3) The production of the film was really high class. The cinematography, score etc clearly had a lot of budget and effort put into themNEGATIVES:1) I did find the film a bit too cringey at times. The singing was too much for me for starters - if it was once or twice it would've been powerful but it happens so often that it becomes sickly. Also Snow's classmates were all just cliché bullies which felt cringey and predictable
2) The end felt very rushed to me, despite the film being over two and a half hours it still felt like it needed more time to wrap things up properly. Snow and Lucy Gray becoming enemies felt out of nowhere and the film leaves more questions than it answers. What happened to Lucy Gray? What are the after effects of Highbottom dying? What happens with the seeming conflict between Snow and Tigriss?3) There were too many references to the original series that felt far too on the nose. I actually thought hearing The Hanging Tree and hearing President Snow's voice at the end were both good call backs, but the references to Katniss and to the Mockingjays were far too on the nose for me.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The acting was mostly alright, but sometimes felt a little forced. To me the worst part was that the most important scene near the end was changed taking away all the power from the main female character. She ended up feeling empty and utterly useless. She couldn't have even been used as eye candy by that point since her camera angles always seemed to catch her in the most unappealing light they possibly could. The other power scenes for the female characters were all ruined for me since it seemed like they over played them times to try to stick it to the man moments. While they were those types of moments, as soon as an actor tries too hard to make it appear that, it has lost all it's power for me.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games movies, for the most part, have been well made and faithful adaptations of the books. So when I turned the final page of Hunger Games: The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes, I was looking forward to the movie much more than I expected to before I started reading the book.Thankfully The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes is another strong and faithful adaptation. We return to the capital 65 years before the events of original Hunger Games films and a few years after the Panem Civil War. We meet a young Cornelius Snow shortly before he and his Capitol class mates mentor tributes in the 10th Annual Hunger Games. We then embark on a three part character study.Firstly, the Capitol looked great. It's not the over the top, bright, excessive and indulgent Capitol we are used to. It's dark and gritty but also a futuristic city seeking to make technological advances. There are times when the CGI is shaky for example when we see cockroaches, rats or explosions but otherwise the film looks great. I especially enjoyed some of the camera work and the interesting use of angles that brought us closer to the action.Viola Davis and Pinter Dinklage were excellent in their roles as Dr Gaul and Dean Highbottom whilst Jason Schwartzman was fantastic as Lucky Flickerman, the movie's only comic relief as weatherman and host of the Hunger Games. The two leads will likely draw several different opinions. They weren't perfect but still had aspects that worked. Tom Blyth played a good Cornelius Snow although it is hard not to think about how majestic Donald Sutherlund is as a older more Powerful Snow. Rachel Zeglar has a great voice which is fully on display as Songbird Lucy Grey Baird, the female tribute from District 12. I wasn't fully sold on other aspects of her performance. That being said, If I had to recast one character in the Hunger Games franchise it would still be Peeta. The chemistry between the leads was questionable at times but perhaps that is to be expected when a boy from the Capitol meets a girl from District 12?I enjoyed the story when I read the book and it was represented well on screen. The movie builds on the lore of The Hunger Games and especially the background of Cornelius Snow in a way that helps us to interpret the originally trilogy in a much more profound way. Director Francis Lawrence originally wanted to split the movie in two but I'm glad it ended up being one movie. However, this resulted in a runtime of 2 hours 37 minutes. The movie squeezed a lot into this time which mostly worked well although there were a couple of instances where I questioned things which happened on screen which I didn't question when reading the book because I had more information available to me at the time. So those who haven't read the book may find it stuffed and the weight of certain scenes may not have the intended impact.The action is fun and brutal at times. At no point did I feel as if they we were catering to a younger audience. This Hunger Games was set in standard oval stadium in the times before the elaborate settings of the future games. This resulted in a larger focus on close combat and hiding which I enjoyed.Overall, The Ballard of Songbirds and Snakes is another well adapted Hunger Games movie. Its dark, gritty and more importantly it tells a standalone story but also a story that enhances our understanding of Cornelius Snow and allows us to view the original trilogy in a way that adds additional layers to the viewing experience. It's a long film and has a lot going on which may not cater to everybody. Highly recommended to fans of the Hunger Games.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: '' The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes '' is a prequel to the '' Hunger Games '' series, following the events taking place before the main story, and explaining how the Hunger Games became the spectacul they ended up being. It is also based on the book by the same name, and, more or less, was a faithful adaption.As a whole, the movie is okay and has its moments. Though the costumes and the settings were just okay, the pace was nicely handled and the games exciting enough. The action scenes well also impressive. In addition, the songs were really good and Lucy Gray was spectacular.However, the story was rushed and the character development of Snow rocky and the few hints here and there left out for the viewer to determent Snow's character were not clear enough amongst the chaos of the games.Finally, the performances were enjoyable, but the leading lady was impressive.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I never had plans to see the "Hunger Games" prequel. After "The Hunger Games" wrapped up with Mockingjay, I was done. I wasn't terribly impressed with the Mockingjay book or the movie. Then my daughters told me how good it was.OK, I'll bite."The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" is an origin story of Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth), later to be known as President Snow. When he was a youngster the districts went to war with the capital and lost, which gave birth to the Hunger Games. It was the Capital's way of punishing the districts for their rebellion.Snow was a small boy during the war, and a teenager in school when the Hunger Games were being "played." At that time the Hunger Games viewership was beginning to wane and Dr. Volumnia Gaul (Viola Davis), the gamemaster, wanted to do something to increase viewership. To do that, the upper class Capital students would have to be mentors to the newest batch of selectees for the tenth annual Hunger Games. Snow got Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler) from District 12.Snow had more of an incentive than any other student to succeed with his underling. He and his family were totally broke and the Plinth Prize money was the only thing that could save them from homelessness and humiliation. He poured everything into helping the soulful Lucy Gray, but was it out of love, selfishness, or both?Even though "Songbirds & Snakes" was two hours and forty-five minutes long, it was enjoyable. I think I looked at my watch once towards the end. They somehow were able to make the actual Hunger Games (meaning the fight to survive) interesting though it was cruder and more rudimentary. Maybe my memory has failed me, but the prequel seemed more vicious, violent, and cutthroat. And that wasn't a bad thing. The performances were great and I think it even evoked more of an emotional response from the viewer. Snow was a mercurial character--sympathetic at times, cunning, smart, and maybe a little sinister. He was worth watching.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'm a big fan of The Hunger Games franchise and I think this movie absolutely does the book justice. This movie is almost exactly how I pictured things in my head while reading the book which is incredibly rare in book to movie adaptations. It adds so much to the world of The Hunger Games and is a must watch even if you're a casual fan.The songs are an integral part of the story and are such a big part of Lucy Gray's character. Rachel Zegler is a good singer and did a phenomenal job bringing Lucy Gray to life. Tom Blyth was an excellent choice for Snow. You're able to see every emotion cross his face as he endures so much throughout the story. I'm very happy with the film overall and I highly recommend taking the time to watch it.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Being old (bordering on decrepit) and never having been a huge fan of teen drama, even when I was a teen myself (in the 18th century), I get the nagging feeling that "The Hunger Games: The Ballad etc." was not exactly meant for me. Mind you, I love post-apocalyptic dystopian fare like any other regular chap, so I thought I'd give this film a go. But well, this is the kind of post-apo yarn where folks are always impeccably dressed with perfect hairdos and teeth, because hey, you may live in a soul-crushing totalitarian society and still care about your physique, right? This made me think of "Logan's Run" (yes, I'm old), which is a compliment I guess... kind of.I particularly enjoyed each time we see Mr. Hottie show off his impeccable torso and abs (5 times in about 2 hours and 30mn, it must have been in his contract). At that point I also decided to mindlessly enjoy the ineffable Peter Dinklage (not his torso and abs though). I felt some schadenfreude at seeing him go through the motions of a Song of Ice and F..., er, a Ballad of Songbirds and Snakes, heartily quaffing wine while philosophizing about the Snow family. Good old times... Speaking of which, what kind of name is Coriolanus Snow?? Ah well, rather than try to make sense of the Shakespearean ref I heartily enjoyed all the wordplays and witty metaphors based on snow ("Snow always lands on top"). Finally the subtle Christian imagery (he gets bitten by a snake, get it???) revealed this flick to be a deep meditation on good and evil in this fallen world of ours, human nature, and white teeth. Especially white teeth.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: What a horrible movie. I expected the hunger games and some singing like the iconic song but this was something else and not in a good way.It seemed more like a movie about a country singer, which is fine but don't call it the hunger games. The characters were weakly developed and the story was miserable. It was hard to empathize with anyone in the movie and honestly quite boring.They could've taken the time to develop the characters but instead wasted all the time on lengthy singing. I get that singing is essential but there's simply too much of it for a movie like the hunger games.Not a movie to watch in the cinema. Just wait for it to stream.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Awful acting from Zegler, i gave her a chance but the movie is like a musical and the depth of the characters is left down trying to make her character more likable and boost her acting career but under the character mask the true nature of her awful personality is seen in through her facial expresions and her eyes. There is non acting talent and love for acting this is pure chase of fame and money !!!In general the movie could be done in more depth slower pase and possibly to make it two parts. Better cast with people full with natural talant and love for acting. There are a lot of young actresses which could do the job better!!

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Sorry but the other 4 movies were wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy better. I fell asleep in the movie theater and was disappointed I didn't watch this online. Honestly it was boring and didn't keep me interested, although I tried hard. The other 4 movies had more essence, a better storyline, more attention to detail and a better understanding of the outlines of the games. The Spanish actress who played the girl who sang country music was not good. Her singing was the only thing that appealed. Viola Davis was just ok as the previous Elizabeth Banks. Not good enough. The Snow guy looked like Ryan Gosling, but overall this movies was not in any comparison of the previous. I hope they don't make a sequel, it's just doing harm.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Because of the good reviews, I thought I'd take a chance on this. It was surprisingly entertaining except it seemed they couldn't find a way to turn the young Snow into a villain without an idiot plot point.Everything made sense until he was sent into the ring to save his friend. He asked his superior to send in the "peacekeepers" but was told that the cameras were on and the public didn't want to see them in there. Then the young Snow was told that the cameras would be off when he went in to retrieve his friend so there would be no record of his entering the ring. After he went in, he killed one of the contestants out of seeming rage though, at that moment, he had more relief at safely retrieving his friend than anger so powerful that he could kill someone.Those 2 idiot plot points allowed him to lie to his girlfriend and ultimately lead her to not trust him and leave him. Had he never killed that contestant, he would have not had an opportunity to lie to his girlfriend and they would have escaped to the north, free. There would never have been a grown up mean Snow, thus no future Hunger Games movies featuring Snow.The other troublesome part was how, when the young lovers stumbled upon a cabin, how was it that the guns made it in there before they got there? And how did she know the guns were in there?So, there were a few things that, i think had they cleaned them up, would have made for a really great movie. As it was, what they ended up with was a movie that was a better than expected sequel (that is a prequel.). So i gave it a rating of 6.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: This prequel presents a remarkable first part that successfully revives the compelling elements of "The Hunger Games" saga, evoking excitement through the portrayal of tributes, the inhumane Capitol management, and poignant metaphors. The smaller arena contributes to an intense atmosphere, maintaining a delicate balance between avoiding explicit deaths and ensuring a family-friendly rating. The contextualization of the early games adds an intriguing layer, highlighting the evolution from the initial to the final games in the original saga.The protagonists, notably Lucy and the nuanced portrayal of the young President Snow, add depth and memorability to the narrative. Despite limited development, secondary characters establish a connection with the audience, eliciting a range of emotions. The film introduces a darker atmosphere not present in the original saga, with memorable scenes like the eerie mockingjays repeating the last words before public executions.However, the second part, while interesting for narrative development, feels rushed, leaving room for a more thorough exploration of characters and consequences. This critique suggests that splitting the narrative into two films could have enhanced the depth of the second part, allowing for additional scenes to intensify the storyline. The justifications for President Snow's personality change, although present, are portrayed quickly and lack convincing depth. Despite these shortcomings, the film stands out for its impactful first part, rivaling or even surpassing key scenes from the original two films.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Personally, I can say as a Hunger Games fan that it's a complete disaster. Normally, it's a perfect series with both a strong plot and an original old film, but this new film is both empty and long. Moreover, the atmosphere is so different that it seems a lot has changed in 65 years (compared to the original film). There's no similarity in the setting, and I find the setting quite dull; it's a major mistake.Characters: The actors weren't bad at their jobs, but they weren't good either. Definitely, the acting in the first film was much better. I can say that the actors were a bit inexperienced, and especially, they couldn't convey fear. There were no scared expressions on their faces; it was as if they were playing a little charming game.And finally, thanks to them for ruining the perfection and indispensability of the film.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Hey, I'm a faithful Hunger Games fan (original series), but I was so moved by my distaste for this story that I needed to leave a review.First, not only was I uninterested in reading the book version of this story, but I was pretty horrified to see/try to understand what the point of it was. The story starts with Snow's family being broke because people stopped watching the hunger games (good), and am I supposed to enjoy watching him slowly devolve? His sister literally gives him the permission not to be a bad person, and he chooses to be one for no apparent reason? Just cuz? None of the classically justifiable villain origin story tropes happen to this kid to make me care that he's evil. He's just bad, and continues to choose to be bad for power's sake (boring). In my opinion, he was bad at the beginning and as soon as he enjoyed/definitely didn't hate doing murder, it just got worse.Second, this is the kind of romantic relationship that one would have in college. He's hot, he'll ruin your life, he'll make you think you're being protected until you break free and someday start writing slam poetry to process your trauma. So, good for her for cutting and running (although not soon enough imo). Her instincts were good at least.Lastly, GOD it was so uncomfortable to watch near the end. When he's just running through the woods with a machine gun because his feelings were hurt I couldn't help but think, "oh god, this is my worst nightmare and also I hope nobody who sees this will think of him as their hero." They will. Someone always will. Why do people waste their time telling stories about these characters? Even worse, with no character development. I don't mind watching someone be evil on screen, but give me a ray of hope.Baseline, I don't care about President Snows origin story. I don't care that he was young once. I don't care that he had a family. I don't even care that he was maybe in something like love. Tell me a story about someone who is challenged and GROWS and changes. That's the kind of story we need right now. Not this.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I read this book when it first released - found it quite muddled and underwhelming, then quickly forgot it. I feel the same about the film. Entertaining enough and watchable, but nothing blew me away. There's just a spark that is missing. Also the characters repeat each others (unbearably annoying) names every 10 seconds - this got very old very fast..The first two Hunger Games films were really elevated by inspired casting choices. Nobody here is close to that level except Viola Davis who steals each of her scenes. She adds much needed charisma and camp energy to this rather flat group of actors. It's actually the kind of performance that could have saved the mediocre Mockingjay films, instead of whatever Julianne Moore was doing.The lead couple's lack of chemistry here actually makes their scenes quite confusing. It was difficult to understand what motivated their actions, especially towards the end. Peter Dinklage is very poor, blatantly bored with this script and just cashing a cheque.Overall it was fun, but I think this could have worked much better as a television series. Dividing each of the three parts of the film into a few hour long episodes would have given some room for the narrative to breathe and build empathy for these characters.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I am a HUGE fan of The Hunger Games but this one is extremely confusing. Is this a Snow origin villain story? Does this explore how the games began? Or is it about something else? .. Well, it's unclear till the end and after.Hated how they made this into a musical and how the film didn't delve as deeply into Coryo's close bond with his mom as the book did. In the book, Ma Plinth is portrayed as a sweet and nurturing mother figure who practically adopts him into the family, providing him with food and support. Her role makes Coryo's betrayal of Sejanus and his eventual demise even more heartbreaking.Yes, there is something that I liked; decent/promising casting.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Where to begin. It felt like torture, nothing makes sense, because nothing has any meaning of any sort. The scenes, the cinematography and the dialogue feel like a 10 year old made the script and put it together overnight. The actors tried their best, but its not their fault the movie is absolute garbage. It was sad to see Peter Dinklage's talent get wasted on this movie. I think the worst part of the movie is how slow and un-interesting everything was.There was so much potential, and after 11 years from the original 2012 movie, this is absolutely pathetic sequel or prequel.Don't recommend to watch even if your life depends on it.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I'd be happy to expand on your review:"I am compelled to express my profound disappointment with 'The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' (2023). Unfortunately, it proved to be a subpar cinematic experience for me. One of the major letdowns lies in the portrayal of action sequences, which, in my view, failed to captivate and fell short of delivering the excitement one would expect from a film of this genre.Moreover, the movie's problem-solving elements left much to be desired, earning it a resounding 0/10 in this department. The narrative seemed to lack the depth and ingenuity necessary to engage the audience on an intellectual level. As a viewer, I found myself yearning for a more compelling and intricate storyline, but sadly, 'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' fell short of meeting these expectations.While I understand that opinions on films can vary, I felt compelled to share my perspective on what I consider to be a lackluster cinematic endeavor. It is my hope that future installments in the Hunger Games series, if any, will manage to recapture the essence and thrill that made the earlier films so memorable."

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: If you're going to make a Hunger Games movie, please make it at least relating to the original series. Before watching the movie, I told my friends we shouldn't watch it as the trailer already looked lame, then we watched the movie and I was right! It felt like a romance movie with the hunger games in the background. No scenes made me emotional, I wanted to go home the first hour but stayed so I could laugh at the stupidity of it. When Katniss sang Hanging Tree in Mockingjay, I wanted to cry. The rawness of her voice and not trying to sound amazing but wanting to portray an emotion of death and sadness was incredible, you can literally hear it. This time around, it was sang as if she was auditioning for Americans Got Talent. I understand it's "The Ballad of the Songbirds" but it's at that point just make it a musical. This shouldnt be part of the OG hunger games series as the games only lasted like an hour out of 2.5 hours of the movie lol. Plus, watching it felt like they were in costumes, idk just me? Like I didnt notice it as much during the other movies because everything just made sense. Anyways, im giving it a 3/10 because it COULDVE been worst, but I don't recommend this to real Hunger Games fans.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Ah, 'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes,' a rollercoaster that's more like a kiddie ride at a local fair. Buckle up, folks - we're in for a lukewarm journey.Coriolanus Snow's transformation is like watching a caterpillar attempt ballet - ambitious but fundamentally awkward. Tom Blyth and Viola Davis give stellar performances, though it feels a bit like winning an Oscar for a school play. And that brief love story? It's the spice equivalent of saltine crackers - a bit bland.Now, the characters. Picture a group of friends you wouldn't invite to your birthday party. That's them. More background and growth? Apparently, that's too much to ask. The pacing is so off; I thought I accidentally switched to 'Hunger Games: The Slow Motion Edition.' Trim it? More like perform a cinematic exorcism.Rachel Zegler's acting is stiffer than a frozen baguette, and the singing scenes? It's like they handed out microphones at a karaoke night for tone-deaf cats. The connection to the original Hunger Games series is shakier than my Wi-Fi during a storm.'The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes' has its moments, like finding a semi-interesting receipt in your wallet - mildly intriguing, but hardly a jackpot. If they iron out these wrinkles, maybe the next chapters will be less like a kiddie ride and more like a rollercoaster with actual loops. Fingers crossed for an upgrade, but hey, miracles happen, right?

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: You can find a review on this everywhere else I will skip to what I felt could have been so interesting and was missed out on.This story has always had deep themes around class warfare, dystopian government, mankind's ability to separate people and make Others Inhuman and able to be treated as cattle. So I think one big missed opportunity is with the plot around the Mentor Program and Corio Snow. Something that has always stuck with me are the servant master relationships we hear about during the American Slavery period. Famously, Thomas Jefferson had a very romantic time with one of his slaves. There should have been more about Lucy Gray, what does she really feel, does she feel grateful? Do they really fall in love or is she playing him? Yes there is that in the beginning but the movie never has the guts to say, these people are in a deep love for each other even though its a sick relationship with an extreme power imbalance. Perhaps they could show her having the power over a foolish Snow. She gets him to rig the games for her and yet has a soft spot for him by the end. Snow could be scandalized by being shown addicted to his "lesser human" girlfriend and therefore his cheating allegations and exile would impact him because he would be deeply grieving feeling that he would never see Lucy again. Lots of ways they could go with this.Also there is just not enough done with the 1960s TV premise. What if this was the first Games in Color? People in The Capital would see the red blood of kids for the first time, would that make a difference on how Panem sees the kids? So many characters could bring you a deep feeling through their eyes of seeing all this awful trauma.How Snow relates to the people on District 12 how it made him change The Hunger Games in how he did how it made him see the people of Panem as human beings and yet how he rationalized seeing himself as worthy of dominating and controlling them at the end, is stuff that can take the viewers on a ride of terror and imagination.The premise, theme, storyline and dialogues of this movie in the right hands are Oscar winning. Too bad they failed on most execution. Another movie that could be life changing wasted in the Hollywood machine. At least it was watchable and had some cool world building so 5/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Having seen, but never been a particularly big fan of "The Hunger Games" movies, I almost didn't go and see his prequel. But it worked out timewise, and I really want to make a concerted effort to see more films at the cinema this year, so I decided to risk it. I was surprisingly impressed with how complex the descent of Snow was handled.With his family near destitute, Coriolanus Snow (Tom Blyth) is banking on graduating from the academy with the prestigious Plinth Prize, which would solve his families' problems. However, at the last moment he, and the rest of this class, are tasked with a final assignment. They each have to mentor a competitor in this years Hunger Games, the 10th annual event, the future of which is in doubt as people have stopped watching. Snow is placed with Lucy Gray Baird (Rachel Zegler) a musical performer from district 12, who is charismatic and personable, but lacking the heart for the violence to come.So, I remembered enough to know that Snow would go on to be the President and antagonist of the later films, so I knew roughly where we were heading. I was surprised at how slowly paced and ... justifiable even ... the stages of his compromised heel turn were. I understand he's more of a monster from the beginning in the book and some people criticised this adaptation for that, but this has to be a more interesting way to go, and Tom Blyth does a good job of keeping things balanced. I liked a lot of the performances, with Viola Davis going big as the current games organiser and Peter Dinklage in a role that becomes more sympathetic as the films goes on.I don't think I'd argue against the film's other criticism though, that's it's long. I did feel its two and half hour run time. With the Hunger Games themselves competed around the halfway point in the film. I'd also say we could have done with a little more differentiation between the other competitors as I often wasn't sure who was who.I don't want to go overboard and over praise a film which does have some issues, but given I had almost no expectation going on, that it was a surprisingly complex and accomplished film, was a nice surprise.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The major beats of the book plot play out more or less exactly as written here in the movie. It falls flat because the author decided this story required "adult pathos" to justify its existence, and, most unfortunately, writes that pathos like a 12 year old making their first big foray into Wattpad. Other than a few vaguely satisfying beats in the (very short) Games sequence, there's nothing here but incredibly amateurish melodrama, and that's all true-to-text.All the best parts of the political intrigue and action/adventure that make the first trilogy so engaging are completely absent, or present only as cameo-style, utterly embarrassing call-backs to those 10-year-old stories that actually interested you. The romance was the worst part of the original series, but here you're begging for it because if it's not the current on-screen focus then you're probably watching a bizarre musical theater kid wet dream where Everybody Has To Stop And Be Impressed By Your Heartfelt Singing That Happens To Be Precisely Suited To The Collective Emotional Moment And Isn't That So Cool. There are literally five or six EXTENDED musical sequences that serve absolutely no plot function, but are wielded by the author like plot points nonetheless, because she's got nothing else to offer while moving the story forward.This flick may not actually be 525,600 minutes long but you could sure fool me by the end. Hard pass.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I understand that many people highlight how faithful they were to the books. That's brilliant but this is a movie made for the mass audiences now.First of all, there's way too much of singing, it gets cheesy and annoying. Secondly, they've tried too hard to remind us our "Katniss Everdeen" it's does not feel natural. I don't like Rachel Ziegler's performance at all she is way too theatrical her accent is too comedic. They have tried to make her Katniss.There must be a Part II for this movie as well I suppose because it left many questions unanswered. I don't want to include spoilers so I will skip those questions.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I have no idea why this story was even written down. Why would we care how snow became snow, ESPECIALLY when 7/8 of the movie he is the complete opposite personality that he should be. Also we get it, Rachel can sing.. the ballads should be inferred...I would have much rather watched a movie about the rebellion, about the 1st hunger games. I still want to know why anyone would care about this story. About a terrible, evil character... just awful... also loved how the hunger games were over first half of the movie... genius... I apparently am in the not popular side of the internet, and it's rare for me to not like a movie...

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" falls short of the high expectations set by its predecessors. Despite its attempt to delve into the origin story of President Snow, the film struggles to captivate audiences. The pacing is uneven, with long stretches of exposition that lack the gripping tension characteristic of the franchise.The choice to center the narrative around a young Snow feels misguided. While exploring the evolution of a villain can be intriguing, the execution here feels forced and fails to humanize the character. Donald Sutherland's charismatic portrayal in the earlier films is sorely missed, leaving a void that the new lead fails to fill convincingly.The film's production design is commendable, successfully recreating the dystopian world of Panem. However, the visual elements alone cannot compensate for the weak character development and a lackluster script. The absence of a strong female protagonist akin to Katniss Everdeen is particularly noticeable, depriving the story of the resilience and depth that defined the previous installments.Furthermore, the film's attempt to provide social commentary on privilege and power lacks subtlety, coming across as heavy-handed and didactic. The subtleties that made the original trilogy thought-provoking are sacrificed for a more straightforward narrative, diminishing the intellectual engagement that characterized earlier films.Despite a few redeeming moments, "The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes" ultimately fails to capture the essence of its predecessors. Fans of the franchise may find it disappointing, as it struggles to live up to the legacy established by the original trilogy. While the film has its merits, it pales in comparison to the thought-provoking and emotionally resonant storytelling that made "The Hunger Games" a cultural phenomenon.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Man,While not a huge fan of the series, I foind the originals decent and enjoyable.To be honest I was enjoying myself thru the first two acts. Despite some truly stupid plot choices.But really just made this move a 0 was the third act. Literally nothing made me care or made sense in the 3rd act. They tried to fit 10+ hours of character development into 15 minutes. This was 10x worse then the last season of game of thrones.Like literally delete the 3rd act and thid goes from a 1 star to a 7 star movie.The producers took some crazy wild drugs and said, "make people feel sorry, but also make him evil in the last 10 minutes,"Seriosly, I live in Wisconsin and could have wrote a script 1000x better then these west coast wannabes.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I had very few expectations going into this movie, in my opinion a Hunger Games prequel sounded like a great premise. But a few things were difficult to watch. Primarily that Lucy Gray was not the protagonist this series deserved. From a wavering southern bell accent (which vacillated wildly) to the near musical territory the movie wandered into, this HG prequel felt like a very long made for premium streaming exclusive. Redemption comes from Tom Blythe, who was phenomenal, but the third act dragged heavily and I found myself asking why he looked like Eminem in District 12. The odd love story between Snow and Gray wasn't helped by the sort of Gypsy bard rebel played by Rachel Zegler.The movie had its moments but I was personally removed from the story every time Zegler had a different accent or used some southern turn of phrase. To me it just fell flat but made canonical sense in what really happened to Snow that sent him down his capital path.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Another movie in the same storyline as the first two. But in contrast, it failed to deliver the same interest. A producer trying to prolong the interest and liking of the first two movies. But that is about as far as it goes. No " Games of Thrones" here, just simple viewing for 5 to 15 year olds. Plays of years before the others, but the theme is exactly the same. Silly TV characters, unnessary violence, assisted by studio scemantics of explosions. Acting sub-standard, and just plainly made for youngsters, which is OK I guess. Will there be a fouth movie? Well, money counts, doesn't it. Overall assessment....lucky to get a 2/10.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: As a long-time fan of the Hunger Games franchise, I approached the new "Hunger Games" with a blend of excitement and caution. Unfortunately, my caution was warranted. The film, from start to finish, felt like a tedious journey through a poorly constructed narrative.First and foremost, the characters in this iteration lacked depth and credibility. Their motivations were unclear, and their actions often felt random, contributing to a disjointed storyline. It was as if the script was generated by an AI like ChatGPT, lacking the human touch that usually brings characters to life.The overall quality of the film was underwhelming. From the CGI effects to the set design, everything seemed to be done with minimal effort and creativity. The dialogues were particularly disappointing, often bordering on nonsensical, which further detached me from the story.Moreover, the plot itself was a letdown. It neither honored the original Hunger Games spirit nor offered anything new or exciting. It was as if the producers simply relied on the franchise's name to carry the movie, without putting in the necessary work to make it stand out.In conclusion, Hunger Games is a forgettable addition to the franchise. It's a stark reminder that not all sequels or spin-offs live up to their names. For future projects, I hope more attention is given to developing engaging characters and a compelling narrative, the very elements that made the original Hunger Games so captivating.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: The movie was pretty good overall - and much better than any expectations for a prequel given the recent history of movie franchises trying to milk more money out of a successful trilogy. The cast is well-done and the story overall isn't like Hunger Games 2 where it was just more or less a replay of Hunger Games 1. I like how the background is constructed in a way that gives information without going through endless boring plots and side plots of characters that aren't memorable.I would have given it a 9/10 (tying my rating for the original) if the ending was better linked to the first Hunger Games. While, a lot is implied by how the movie ends. I would have liked more linkage on Snow's health issues in the Mockingjay movies where he had poisoned himself in order to poison and kill all his enemies. Whether it be by the way he did in this movie or some other method, there should have been more hints that he was willing to hurt himself to wipe out all his enemies. Unless they are planning to make a sequel to the prequel, I think they could have added about 5 minutes of screen time to explain how exactly he became President Snow.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Brutally long and uninspiring movie. The lead character is unbearable to watch. Her accent is something like an O'l southern accent mixed with a really poor Irish accent. Her facial expressions, and unnecessary singing made me ask myself several times how much longer is this movie. The worst part is I bought it instead of renting it.I enjoyed all of the other hunger games movies, the acting was better, the characters had better chemistry, the storyline flowed better. I don't know if they are going to make more movies to follow this one. However if they do I hope they get a new cast and director.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I was waiting for this movie for so long because of the backlash that Rachel Zegler had - due to her remarks about the previous Snow white movie - and I was waiting for her to prove how fantastic she is and how the world was putting her in a bad light for simply having an opinion!She proved that she is an outstanding actor, who has magnetism and beautiful vocals!I never read the book, but thoroughly enjoyed the other movies and now I feel as though this movie was one of my favourites, it interesting to learn how the whole games started off and how it became televised to the people of the Capitol.President Snows - younger back story - was also very interesting to discover and shows the viewers how he became as cold as his last name states.It's funny how love can make you go crazy and risk it all...But also risking it all for someone and then showing your true colours.. and then realising you didn't truly even know one another, when it's too late, can also make you go a bit insane also,Snow felt as though he wasted his time and energy and I get that, but he was never going to last with Lucy as she had a totally different, free-spirited mindset that would never have obided by the capitols rules.Very interesting story, go see it!!

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Disjointed, unclear motivation, mannequins for characters, overly long. I had a real hard time following the evolving motivation of Snow and part three left me scratching my head. He betrays the rebels, acts in their defense and then .... I don't really know. The near final scene set near the cabin on the lake was emblematic of the disjointed story line. Snows final emergence as the cold villain we know from the sequels is not convincing. A waste of a few hours. Some good performances scattered throughout, Dinklage is solid as usual and the game show host is fun and Viola Davis's wardrobe and make up is the best thing about the movie.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: I think the best way to describe this film is disjointed. It felt like they spent too little time on each of the characters but at the same time scenes seemed to drag on and the dialogue was boring. There was no chemisry between the two main characters and their romance was high unbelievable but is the main point of the film. It jumps from the capitol, to the games, to district 12 so much I can't help but think it would've been better as a tv show so it could've properly been broken down into different parts. Some things were just highly unrealistic too such as a bunch of Capitol studens chanting to free a tribute? Never going to happen. Also Lucy trying to kiss Snow within what a daty of meeting him? Also how was there so little fighting or action in a film about people fighting to the death? Some plot points just didn't make sense like how on earth Snow sent a bird with his friend confessing treason then being upset when his friend was killed to the last 30 minutes of the film where the characers did a 360 and admitted killing people without telling us who. It had good potential and I liked he easter eggs to the later movies but overall missed the mark for me. Just go see The Marvels instead.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: It's actually a good starting movie. There were some fictional mistakes. But I think he was able to send the right references to a beautiful story we know.Also, character selections were successful.It's actually a good starting movie. There were some fictional mistakes. But I think he was able to send the right references to a beautiful story we know.Also, character selections were successful.It's actually a good starting movie. There were some fictional mistakes. But I think he was able to send the right references to a beautiful story we know.Also, character selections were successful.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content: Honestly, I made an IMDb account to write a review for this movie after reading some other ones. Saw it opening night and I think it might be one of my favorite movies of the year. The casting was amazing, the story was super close to the book, the music beautiful. Everything about this movie was really well done. I read a couple of other reviews and I have to say that most who don't like this movie seem to never have like the hunger games in the first place. If you are a hunger games fan I really believe you'll enjoy this movie. The acting was superb -Snow was incredible and so was Lucy. I give it a 9/10 because there were some parts where it felt a little gimmicky and it was on the longer side. Overall, a super enjoyable movie. I'd definitely recommend if you liked anything about the original hunger games (books or movies). Idk how these reviews work but if you can lmk what you think.

Title: The Hunger Games: The Ballad of Songbirds & Snakes
Reviewer_Content:
The first Hunger Games with Jennifer Lawrence was a very good film. It was fresh and new and Katniss Everdeen was a great movie character.A side character in that trilogy ( 4 films ) was President Snow, this film is a prequel to the original films showing him in his youth before his rise to power.The film is split into 3 parts.Part 1 - is an introduction to Snow and his friends/fellow students and also the tributes of the 10th hunger games.Part 2 - is the 10th Hunger games
